title: Lonmin To Extend Job Cuts Amid Platinum Slump
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Jul 23, 2015, 19:00 BST - UK Markets closed Lonmin To Extend Job Cuts Amid Platinum Slump By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 26 minutes ago View Photo 

The London-listed miner Lonmin (LSE: LMI.L - news ) is to pave the way on Friday for a major capital‎-raising when it expands a cost-cutting programme sparked by a slump in platinum prices. 
Sky News has learnt that Lonmin will announce alongside its quarterly production report that it intends to axe more than 5,000 jobs, an increase from the 3,500 signalled in May. 
The company will also say that it is reviewing options to strengthen its balance sheet, which insiders say could mean a rights issue as well as new debt facilities. 
It will not at this stage ‎set out firm proposals for a rights issue or other capital-raising measures, however, one source added. 
News of Lonmin's plans comes as platinum, along with other commodities, extend recent price declines, although brokers have suggested in the last few days that a rally may be around the corner. 
Platinum is used most commonly in vehicles' catalytic converters as well as jewellery. 
The expanded cost-cutting programme to be unveiled by the world's third-biggest platinum producer ‎will follow a five-month strike in South Africa last year at its flagship Marikana mine. 
The 3,500 job cuts announced in May equated to roughly 10% of its cost base, it said at the time. 
It is unclear whether the decision to increase the figure to more than 5,000 could provoke a further round of strikes. 
Ben Magara, Lonmin's chief executive, said in May: "The mining industry is going through another challenging economic cycle and we need to make difficult decisions to maintain the resilience of our business and protect employment. 
"Our cost controls so far have been encouraging but the price of our metals is beyond our control and we need to make further savings, including seeking voluntary reductions in our labour force which represents around 60% of our total costs." 
Lonmin's existing borrowing agreements are due to expire next year, and some analysts believe a combination of new debt and equity will be required to restore the company to a secure footing. 
"It remains unclear how Lonmin could transform itself into a producer with the ability to generate cash through the [economic] cycle," analysts at UBS (NYSEArca: FBGX - news ) said earlier this month. 
At one stage, Lonmin had a market value of £7bn, but a protracted decline in its share price - including a two-thirds fall during the last 12 months - means it is now worth just £437m. 
Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) , the FTSE-100 miner and commodities trader, announced earlier this year that it would spin off its 23.9% stake in Lonmin, a deal it concluded last month. 
A Lonmin spokesman declined to comment.
